conjunction, adverb, &amp; preposition.description: In the intervening period between (the time mentioned) and the time under consideration, typically the present.
examples: she has suffered from depression since she was sixteen
the worst property slump since the war
I've felt better since I've been here
she ran away on Friday and we haven't seen her since
synonyms: on account of the fact that
in view of the fact that

examples: delegates were delighted, since better protection of rhino reserves will help protect other rare species
synonyms: in view of the fact that

examples: the settlement had vanished long since

origin: Late Middle English: contraction of obsolete sithence, or from dialect sin (both from dialect sithen thereupon, afterward, ever since).
